lead_paragraph: DELFINER--Henry, of Lexington, MA passed away January 3, 2016. Born in Vienna, Henry and his sister fled Austria on the day of the Anschluss, coming to the United States via Paris. He graduated from Amherst College in 1943, joined the Army, serving with the 88th Infantry Division in northern Italy. On May 2, 1945, acting as the translator for his commanding officer, Henry took the surrender of a whole German corps, including the First German Parachute Division. Decorated with the Bronze Star, he left the Army as a major. After the War, he was instrumental in reclaiming the family business from the Nazis, thereafter running the Herzmansky Department Store himself. He was also involved with the family business Greene Tweed of Kulpsville, PA through most of his adult life. He received a Ph.D. from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and taught at Tufts University as a professor of International Relations. His class on "Understanding International News," which he taught in the Experimental College at Tufts was very popular. After retiring from Tufts in 1987, he continued to write scholarly articles about the history of central Europe. In 1999, concerned with a lack of balance in political views in academia, he joined with Hadley Arkes, Edward N. Ney Professor in American Institutions at Amherst College in establishing the Colloquium on the American Founding, a twice-yearly weekend series of lectures and seminars where well-known national figures and influential conservative speakers were invited to present their views. He will be remembered for his kindness and his extraordinary generosity. Beloved husband of Barbara (Schudawa) Delfiner. Devoted father of Hannah Delfiner, Michael Delfiner and his wife Tracey, and Ruth Delfiner and her husband Paul Cooke. Loving brother of Charlotte Sperber. Cherished grandfather of Allon Bloch and his wife Annelise, Benjamin Delfiner, Rebecca Delfiner and her fiance Tom, and Emma Cooke. Proud great-grandfather of Alexander Bloch. 1/3
